organic_results.title: One-parent households and achievement: Economic and behavioral explanations of a small effect
organic_results.snippet: Results from analyses of High School and Beyond show that students from one-parent households have significantly lower grades and test scores than do those from two-parent households. Students from one-parent households have test scores that are about. 30 standard deviations lower, but this finding seems to be explained by differences in race-ethnicity and the educational level of parents. Both mother absence and father absence reduce students' grades, by. 17 and. 27 standard deviations, respectively. Controls on race …

publication_info.summary: LM Mulkey, RL Crain, AJC Harrington - Sociology of education, 1992 - JSTOR
